questions.question_text: An organization wants to implement a solution that allows for automated logical controls for network defense. An engineer plans to select an appropriate network security component, which automates response actions based on security threats to the network. Which of the following would be MOST appropriate based on the engineer's requirements?

discussion.content: Answer is A.

HIPS (Host-base Intrusion Prevention System): An IPS installed on a host or virtual machine that blocks activity it identifies as malicious. NIDS (Network-based Intrusion Detection System): An IDS that inspects network traffic often at the packet level to identify threats but does not block it.

questions.question_text: A highly complex password policy has made it nearly impossible to crack account passwords. Which of the following might a hacker still be able to perform?

discussion.content: This is a very poorly worded question. Should we assume the answer still needs to be related to passwords? Is there anything in the question that indicates the hacker could not conduct an ARP poisoning attack?

comments.content: I think its all d questions actually lol

I just see no way that you can eliminate A or B!! MAC address spoofing, according to Professor Messer, has little to NO security and allows replay attacks. the only way I can attempt to narrow down is with session ID's that thwart attacks but I feel that wouls stop both A and B. This question sucks!

discussion.content: this question awfully lacks details....

A Pass-the-Hash (PtH) attack is a technique whereby an attacker captures a password hash (as opposed to the password characters) and then simply passes it through for authentication and potentially lateral access to other networked systems. The threat actor doesn’t need to decrypt the hash to obtain a plain text password. PtH attacks exploit the authentication protocol, as the passwords hash remains static for every session until the password is rotated. Attackers commonly obtain hashes by scraping a system’s active memory and other techniques. The answer is A.
Why its not C or D because we can eliminate those they are plain text attacks. The question states that they strengthen their passwords. The only one left is A. B is not a password attack

comments.content:
I'd select A as well. Hybrid Attack would possibly break the complex password, that is not an option in the question. 

If an attacker can obtain the hash of a user password, it is possible to present the hash (without cracking it) to authenticate to network protocols such as CIFS.

discussion.content: The answer is A, as it suggests a really complex password is used so it can't be brute force/dictionary attack. No matter how secure the password is, if the user gets the hash he can resend the username and hashed password to create his own session.
In pass the hash attacker steals a hashed user credential and without cracking it, reuses it to trick an authentication system into creating a new authentication session on the same network
B it is
Would go with B on this one. They are kind of pushing the “no password related attacks” with the nearly impossible keyword

comments.content: They aren't pushing "no password related attacks", just that the password is highly complex. A highly complex password won't matter if you can gain access to the hash and crack the hash instead (assuming it's not salted which this makes no mention of)

discussion.content: It has to be pass the hash, an arp poisoning may be used to intercept the clear text of the hash but the pass the hash attack would be used to break the heart of the user.....</3 RIP

A - pass the hash - if the network is using NTLM this is definitely possible as all the hashed passwords will be stored locally on the PC database. Password complexity won’t matter.

B - arp poisoning - the only one not related to passwords and could allow for session jijacking or man in the middle attacks.

C - birthday attack - if stored passwords use a weak hashing algorithm then yes it doesn’t matter how strong the passwords are - we are still vulnerable.

D - brute force - assuming the passwords are very complex, we can almost rule this one out but not entirely.

Answer: B - I think what this one is trying to get at is that the company may think they have a perfect password policy, they don’t use NTLM and have a good hashing algorithm. 

However, that ALONE is not enough because arp poisoning attacks don’t care about any of that as they can circumvent it, lead to session hijacking and MITM attacks.
A. pass the hash replaces the need for stealing the plaintext password with merely stealing the hash and using that to authenticate.

B. . According to the specifications, WPA2 networks must use CCMP by default (WPA2-CCMP),
CCMP, also known as AES CCMP, is the encryption mechanism that has replaced TKIP

As a reminder:
WEP >>> RC4, WPA >>> TKIP, WPA2 >>> AES
Most secure=AES
AES - highest encryption standard
B - WPA2 encryption protocol supports AES

TKIP and AES are two different types of encryption that can be used by a Wi-Fi network. TKIP is actually an older encryption protocol introduced with WPA to replace the very-insecure WEP encryption at the time. ... AES is a more secure encryption protocol introduced with WPA2

questions.question_text: When connected to a secure WAP, which of the following encryption technologies is MOST likely to be configured when connecting to WPA2-PSK?

discussion.content:
This question was on the test. Taken Jan 24, 2020 
Provided answer/s is/are correct. I say, (is/are) because ironically, there was only one option to chose from, and looking at the answers, it makes sense; cause either one is the opposite of the other. I picked option B. -- You could pick option C, and still get credit for it, or maybe NOT? because the computer might be told to give credit for choosing one of the two options, and not give credit when you pick the other... (What matters is, I passed the test!)
It didn't say choose 2..wtf

Answer: B, C
See pages 629, 630, and 631.
Explanation:
Fundamental difference is that CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) happens in authenticated sessions when the server trusts the user/browser, while XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) doesn't need an authenticated session and can be exploited when the vulnerable website doesn't do the basics of validating or escaping input.
CSRF is also known as XSRF.
Was on the test.
Why 2 answers? The verb is singular, so should be the answer.

comments.content: It also doesn't have "(Choose two)" in the question

“Fundamental difference is that CSRF (Cross-site Request forgery) happens in authenticated sessions when the server trusts the user/browser, while XSS (Cross-Site scripting) doesn’t need an authenticated session and can be exploited when the vulnerable website doesn’t do the basics of validating or escaping input.”
B and C is the correct answer

discussion.content:
I would choose AE
Both of them need victims to get authenticated.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the main difference between an XSS vulnerability and a CSRF vulnerability?

choices.C: CSRF needs the victim to be authenticated to the trusted server.
choices.E: CSRF does not need the attacker to be authenticated to the trusted server.
choices.D: CSRF does not need the victim to be authenticated to the trusted server.
choices.B: XSS does not need the victim to be authenticated to the trusted server.
choices.A: XSS needs the attacker to be authenticated to the trusted server.

questions.question_text:
A group of developers is collaborating to write software for a company. The developers need to work in subgroups and control who has access to their modules.
Which of the following access control methods is considered user-centric?

discussion.content:
This question was on the test. Taken Jan 24, 2020 
Provided answer is correct.

In computer security, discretionary access control is a type of access control defined by the Trusted Computer System Evaluation Criteria "as a means of restricting access to objects based on the identity of subjects and/or groups to which they belong.
Remember Discretionary = FUBU for user by user.
"user-centric" only DAC where Owner of the file/folder sets permissions.

The developers need to work in subgroups and control who has access to their modules.
DEVELOPERS CONTROL WHO HAS ACCESS

DAC can be user-base sometimes call user-centric
https://books.google.com/books?id=5-jJDwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=user-centric&f=false
